title: Windows Endpoint Analysis Challenge 1
instructions:
You've been assigned to remotely investigate a compromised Windows workstation as part of a live incident response scenario. The affected system has been imaged and all necessary forensic artifacts have been gathered. Your objective now is to investigate the scope of the compromise and identify any persistence mechanisms installed by the attacker.

Use your endpoint analysis skills to conduct the investigation and answer the questions below.

Challenge File:

  • 03_Endpoint_Security/Windows/Challenges/challenge.exe

To start the challenge, execute challenge.exe in an Administrator-level command prompt. Make sure to not close the program or window until after you've completed the challenge. However, you can temporarily minimize it. After running the executable, you can open additional command prompt windows to complete the investigation.

After completing the challenge, you can clean up and restore the system by terminating the challenge.exe process (Press Ctrl + C). Then, run challenge.exe -revert.

questions.question: Simulate the compromise by running challenge.exe in an Administrator-level command prompt. Make sure to not close the program or window until after you've completed the challenge. However, you can temporarily minimize it. Enter "done" to continue.
What port is the challenge.exe malware listening on?
questions.hint: The netstat command can be paired with several useful options to display network connections and listening ports.

questions.question: What is the Process ID (PID) of the malware? This answer cannot be verified, but it's required for the next question(s).
questions.hint: The netstat command can be paired with several useful options to display network connections, listening ports, and their associated Process IDs (PIDs).

questions.question: List all of the loaded DLL modules for the listener's associated process. What are the names of the two DLLs that start with the letter m?
questions.hint: Read the help page for the (tasklist /?) command to figure out the option that can list a process' loaded DLL modules.

questions.question: What is the name of the malware's parent process?
questions.hint: There are several ways to find out this information. The wmic command can be used to pull back specific details about a process, including its parent's process name.

questions.question: List all the shared resources on the local system. What is the name of the share that the attacker created?
What path or resource does the attacker's share point to?
The attacker created a Run entry to establish persistence on the system. What is the full path of the registry key?
questions.hint: You can use the Autoruns utility (Sysinternals) to identify abnormal autorun entries. Or, you can query the well-known autorun entries manually using reg query.

questions.question: What is the name of the malicious entry the attacker created in the previously identified registry key?
What is the full file or image path that this registry entry points to?
What is the name of the backdoor service installed by the attacker?
questions.hint: You can use the Autoruns utility (Sysinternals) to identify abnormal services.

questions.question: What is the START_TYPE configuration of the service?
questions.hint: Once you've identified the name of the backdoor service, you can use the sc __ command to query its configuration.

questions.question: What is the full path to the service binary?
What is the name of the scheduled task created by the attacker?
questions.hint: You can use the Autoruns utility (Sysinternals) to identify abnormal scheduled tasks. Or, you can query system tasks manually using the schtasks utility.

questions.question: What is the full path to the executable that the scheduled task runs?
At what time is the scheduled task set to run?
Excellent work! Clean up and restore the system by terminating the challenge.exe process (Press Ctrl + C). Then, run challenge.exe -revert. Afterwards, enter "done" to continue.
